title: FirstFT: Passing of the baton at KKR
text:
There was a very public handing over of the baton on Wall Street yesterday to a new generation of dealmakers.

Henry Kravis and George Roberts, co-founders of private equity group KKR, announced they were stepping back from day-to-day operations.

The pair were memorialised in the 1989 book Barbarians at the Gate, which recounted KKR's conquest for the conglomerate RJR Nabisco. The $25bn deal came to symbolise a new kind of scorched-earth approach to finance and dealmaking and cemented the reputations of Kravis and Roberts. Jerome Kohlberg, their mentor at Bear Stearns, was the other founder. He died in 2015.

The hardball approach to business paid off and more than 30 years later KKR owns a portfolio of companies worth more than $650bn that employs over 800,000 people.

Longtime co-presidents Scott Nuttall, 48, and Joe Bae, 49, will take over from the cousins Kravis and Roberts, who founded their eponymous firm in 1976. Both successors joined KKR in their twenties. Bae built KKR's Asian business while Nuttall focused on the firm's capital markets and credit activities.

“We could not be more excited about this moment in time,” said Kravis, 77, and Roberts, 78, in a joint statement. “There is such a huge need for private capital to support businesses, and KKR still has so much potential even 45 years later.”

Antoine Gara and Mark Vandevelde describe how Kravis and Roberts transformed KKR into a diversified institution — almost like the conglomerates they once broke up.

No one understood the concept of “other people's money” better than Henry Kravis and George Roberts 35 years ago, says Lex.

What's KKR without the K and the R? Due Diligence, our corporate finance newsletter, looks at what lies ahead for the buyout firm.

FT Alphaville remembers some of the best lines from the classic novel that sealed their reputations.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. IMF board backs Georgieva The IMF's executive board has opted to retain Kristalina Georgieva as managing director, saying they have “full confidence” in her ability, despite allegations she pressured World Bank staff when she was its chief executive to manipulate data to China's benefit.

2. Evergrande bondholders say they have not received interest payments International investors say they have not received interest payments totalling $148m on dollar-denominated Evergrande bonds they own. The deadline for the payment was midday today in Hong Kong, according to two people familiar with the matter.

3. US oil benchmark hits seven-year high The price of US crude oil hit a fresh seven-year high yesterday on fears that fuel demand was recovering faster from last year's economic slowdown than producers could bring supply to the market. American consumers are paying more for fuel at the pump than they have since 2014.

4. Kim tells North Korea officials to boost living standards Kim Jong Un has demanded that officials boost North Korea's living standards as his regime struggles to come to grips with a self-acknowledged “food crisis”.

5. Southwest flight delays drag on into a fourth day Southwest Airlines blamed air traffic control and weather as widespread flight cancellations and delays stretched into a fourth day, while its pilots union said the disruptions signalled how the airline's overtaxed operations were buckling under stress.

Coronavirus digest

  • US Covid cases drop by 22%, raising hopes the worst may be over, but experts urge caution amid concerns over new variants and vaccine hesitancy.

  • Merck has asked US regulators to authorise the first antiviral pill to treat Covid-19 in a move health experts hope could help ease the pandemic.

  • Many countries' Covid responses are being hampered by population data glitches. Imperfect figures mean nations do not know how many residents have been vaccinated.

The day ahead

IMF World Economic Outlook published The IMF's embattled chief Kristalina Georgieva is expected to present the fund's latest report on the outlook for the global economy.

The Future of Climate Finance The FT hosts a virtual forum to explore the ever-expanding world of climate finance. Join the live broadcast here.

What else we're reading and listening to

How Elon Musk's new rocket could transform space race Elon Musk hopes the SpaceX Starship will help take humans to Mars. Rivals fear the entrepreneur will not only dominate deep space exploration, but disrupt the economics of the launch business and transform the space race.

The moment of truth over Taiwan is getting closer Would the US go to war over Taiwan? That question has seemed fairly abstract for decades. Now it is increasingly urgent, writes Gideon Rachman, as the US and China engage in a dangerous game of military poker.

Nobel Prize economists turned statistics into insight Tim Harford pays tribute to the winners of this year's Nobel Prize for economics. He says Joshua Angrist and Guido Imbens developed “a toolkit to help researchers discern crisp causal relationships from fuzzy natural experiments”.

Why quitting your job is good for the economy Much has been written about why Americans are quitting their jobs in higher numbers than at any point since the turn of the millennium, writes Sarah O'Connor. It isn't just an interesting sociological phenomenon, she says, but has an under-appreciated bearing on pay and productivity.

‘My life expectancy was nine years old' Plenty of people in their 30s, 40s and even 50s have yet to start saving for retirement, and are anxious about how to begin, including this week's Money Clinic guest David, who was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis and never thought he would reach retirement. But thanks to a revolutionary new treatment, he is now planning for when he ends work.

A global AI bill of rights is desperately needed The Bill of Artificial Intelligence Rights proposed by the White House science advisers could ensure a person's right to know if and how AI is making decisions about them, writes Anjana Ahuja. It could enshrine freedom from algorithms.

Technology

What you need to know about the new iPhone 13 The looks won't wow you but the camera and battery life are the real joy of Apple's latest iPhone, says our reviewer Jamie Waters.
